issue.title: Add accessibility attributes
issue.body:
I've been reading through some ARIA docs and realized this component should probably just be a [`progress`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/progress) element, but if not it at least needs the [`role=progressbar`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/roles/progressbar_role) attribute.

In addition, I need to read through the docs, but there are some ARIA properties (labels, `valuenow`, etc) that should be set, and some guidance documented on the proper way to place this in a page for screen readers.

issue.title: feature: add support for ejson
issue.body:
PR for #3.

co-body is the package koa-body uses to parse the request body, but koa-body will only do that when content-type is in a small, non-extensible list of types that does not include application/ejson.

A co-worker and I have already had one successful day using this fork without any issues so far.

comment.body: Okay yeah, that does look pretty great 👍 I'm pretty cramped for time this week, but I'll keep this tagged on my end and try to merge and release this week or weekend. Thanks!!!

issue.title: Support for application/ejson
issue.body:
I'm using application/ejson with the real data API to ensure my dates are stored as dates and not as strings.

I'm finally getting mongodb-local-data-api set up at work because the real data API is so slow to develop with. (I hope this is because I'm still using a free cluster for my proof of concept, and it will be faster once we start paying...)

When I send a request with application/ejson in the content-type header to mongodb-local-data-api, I get back a 400 and see messages like this logged to the console:

```
Attempting to connect to: undefined
Error handling request: Collection name must be a String
```

It looks to me like the koa-body middleware is not parsing the request body because application/ejson is not in its hard-coded list of acceptable types for JSON and there is no option to extend that. 😢 

I can change my content-type to application/json and it starts to work but the data I'm sending in EJSON format is not being saved correctly.

I'm using the EJSON object in the bson package to stringify and parse this format. I think mongodb-local-data-api could use the same package to do the opposite depending on the content-type and accept headers it receives.

I've never used Koa, but I think this wouldn't be too hard to add so can attempt to send a PR if you think is this is correct.

comment.body: (Also, yes, once you upgrade the DB out of the free/sandbox mode, it's *much* faster, at least in my experience.)

issue.title: Support for application/ejson
issue.body:
I'm using application/ejson with the real data API to ensure my dates are stored as dates and not as strings.

I'm finally getting mongodb-local-data-api set up at work because the real data API is so slow to develop with. (I hope this is because I'm still using a free cluster for my proof of concept, and it will be faster once we start paying...)

When I send a request with application/ejson in the content-type header to mongodb-local-data-api, I get back a 400 and see messages like this logged to the console:

```
Attempting to connect to: undefined
Error handling request: Collection name must be a String
```

It looks to me like the koa-body middleware is not parsing the request body because application/ejson is not in its hard-coded list of acceptable types for JSON and there is no option to extend that. 😢 

I can change my content-type to application/json and it starts to work but the data I'm sending in EJSON format is not being saved correctly.

I'm using the EJSON object in the bson package to stringify and parse this format. I think mongodb-local-data-api could use the same package to do the opposite depending on the content-type and accept headers it receives.

I've never used Koa, but I think this wouldn't be too hard to add so can attempt to send a PR if you think is this is correct.

comment.body:
Yeah, if you wanted to make a PR that would be great!

Supporting ejson is in my personal todo list, but very low priority for me since I don't use it.

If you make a PR, I will test it locally and then (probably) tidy it slightly before cutting a release, but I'll be sure to credit you. ❤️

issue.title: Footer bar in REPL throws console error on hover
issue.body: **What I did:** Open a REPL in Firefox `105.0.2 (64-bit)` on macOS `12.4`, then open the dev console, then hover my mouse over the footer promo. **What happened:** On (every? most? there's probably throttling going on) mouseover events, I get a thrown console error: ``` Error: Attempted to prefetch a URL that does not belong to this app ``` **What I expect to happen:** The error should not be thrown.

comment.body:
Actually, it looks like this is related to https://github.com/sveltejs/kit/issues/6463 which was addressed here https://github.com/sveltejs/kit/pull/6518 but the issue doesn't seem to be addressed entirely since I would expect this error to not be thrown (at most a `console.warning`).

From the [SvelteKit docs](https://kit.svelte.dev/docs/link-options#disabling-options) it looks like we could just add the `data-sveltekit-prefetch="off"` on some parent node, at least for now.

issue.title: Footer bar in REPL throws console error on hover

payload.description: Run a local version of the MongoDB Atlas "Data API".

commits.message: fix: enforce application/json mime type response

payload.description: Run a local version of the MongoDB Atlas "Data API".

issue.title: Some confusion getting started using for the first time
issue.body:
Hello,

My team is considering using the Data API and wanted to know if there was an option for local development and so I came across your project. Thank you for releasing it. 

I ran into some issues while trying it out:

The README made me think I had to use the `setup` function which didn't make sense to me, but I eventually got a query to work with curl after studying the source code. Would have been nice if the README showed an example using curl and then I think some of my confusion would have been minimized.

Had to look in the code to see the URLs should start with /action instead of the longer URLs in the examples in the Data API docs. I think this is OK because we can configure any base URL we want and just append /find, /insertOne, etc.

Did not know what to put in `dataSource` until I saw the code that said it was ignored.

Only POST requests seem to work but some of the examples in the official docs show GET requests. Also not a big deal but was getting not found errors until I realized this.

When my local MongoDB doesn't require a username or password, omitting those options doesn't work. Using a simple `--url` option without username and password in the URL works, though.

Sending `Accept: application/ejson` seems to return the same data as application/json. I don't know yet if we will want to use ejson but I'm guessing you don't in your projects since it's not implemented?

In the end, I got it working so it's very nice to have the option of using your tool. I know I could have submitted multiple issues but didn't want to spam you.

I have a question. Do you use this on projects for work and find it valuable? I think I'd be OK with just using Atlas but I like having options, too, and don't want to prevent anybody from developing offline if they want to.

Thanks again.

issue.title: Outstanding bugs in the MongoDB Data API
issue.body:
These are known issues with the MongoDB Atlas Data API, which are implemented in this version for accuracy.

I'll write them as checkboxes, and as the MongoDB dev team fixes them, I'll update this library.

- [x] The `/deleteOne` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`
- [x] The `/deleteMany` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`
- [x] The `/find` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`
- [x] The `/findOne` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`
- [x] The `/insertOne` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`
- [x] The `/insertMany` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`
- [x] The `/replaceOne` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`
- [x] The `/updateOne` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`
- [x] The `/updateMany` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`

Other things possibly not bugs but will probably change later:

- [x] The `/insertMany` doesn't return the `insertedCount` on the response.
- [x] The `/updateMany` doesn't return the `updatedCount` on the response.

issue.title: Outstanding bugs in the MongoDB Data API
issue.body:
These are known issues with the MongoDB Atlas Data API, which are implemented in this version for accuracy.

I'll write them as checkboxes, and as the MongoDB dev team fixes them, I'll update this library.

- [x] The `/deleteOne` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`
- [x] The `/deleteMany` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`
- [x] The `/find` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`
- [x] The `/findOne` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`
- [x] The `/insertOne` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`
- [x] The `/insertMany` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`
- [x] The `/replaceOne` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`
- [x] The `/updateOne` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`
- [x] The `/updateMany` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`

Other things possibly not bugs but will probably change later:

- [x] The `/insertMany` doesn't return the `insertedCount` on the response.
- [x] The `/updateMany` doesn't return the `updatedCount` on the response.

comment.body: MongoDB Atlas Data API is out of beta, and these things are all finally resolved.

issue.title: MongoDB Data API is out of beta
issue.body:
Thanks to the note in #1 from @da7a90-backup I was informed that v1 is out.

With that, I'll update this library to v1 as well! 🎉

The breaking change is basically just on the init side, but also note that the Data API v1 has more consistent responses (when it returns JSON it always sets `Content-Type: application/json` instead of sometimes `text/plain`).

### Added
- Full test suite (it's the demo code) that actually connects to a MongoDB Data API
  instance to verify that all requests are being made correctly. (Note to my future
  self: this is using a free version, which will likely be automatically spun down
  due to inactivity. I will need to go spin it back up for tests to pass.)
### Changed
- BREAKING: Simplified the interface a bit, by requiring the fully qualified URL instead of region
  and/or app ID. Here are the [MongoDB URL docs](https://www.mongodb.com/docs/atlas/api/data-api-resources/#base-url).
- BREAKING: Renamed `cluster` to `dataSource` to match their parameter names better.
- Change the default-vs-overrides a bit: you don't *need* to specify the `dataSource`, `database`,
  or `collection` properties at initialization. If you do, you can still specify them at
  the request to override the defaults.

# Migration

Anywhere you are instantiating `mongodb`, you will need to...

Change `cluster` to `dataSource`:

```diff
const db = mongodb({
	apiKey,
	apiUrl,
-	cluster,
+	dataSource,
	database,
	collection,
})
```

If you are using `apiId` / `apiRegion` you will need to construct the URL yourself:

```diff
const db = mongodb({
	apiKey,
-	apiId,
-	apiRegion,
+	apiUrl: 'https://data.mongodb-api.com/app/YOUR_ID/endpoint/data/v1',
	dataSource,
	database,
	collection,
})
```

(Look at the [MongoDB Data API docs](https://www.mongodb.com/docs/atlas/api/data-api-resources/#base-url) for additional guidance on URLs.)

comment.body: Ugh yes, I see that now, thanks for the heads up 🤦‍♂️ I'll fix it early next week.

comment.body:

Thanks again!

issue.title: Sample for downloading an attachment?
issue.body:
I've been reading through the JMAP specs and the Fastmail docs, and I can't figure out how to use JMAP to fetch an individual attachment from an email.

* Is this even possible? I can use other methods to get the attachment bytes, but it has all the other metadata (mime-type, name, blob id, etc) so that it feels like it should be right there.
* If it's possible, can it be added to this repo as an example? (I could make a PR once I understand it.)
* If it's not possible, is there a related Fastmail API that I could use instead?

pull_request.title: CLI designed and dependency licensing considerations
pull_request.body:
* The general structure of the code, as well as the command line options, have been finalized.
* The core code for the CLI portion has been added.
* The CLI code makes use of dependencies. Licenses for all dependencies that are used in the distributed, compiled code will be kept in a new `licensing` folder.
* All dependencies, whether for distributed or development, will be pinned to exact values for clearer licensing and security analysis.

issue.title: Footer bar in REPL throws console error on hover
issue.body: **What I did:** Open a REPL in Firefox `105.0.2 (64-bit)` on macOS `12.4`, then open the dev console, then hover my mouse over the footer promo. **What happened:** On (every? most? there's probably throttling going on) mouseover events, I get a thrown console error: ``` Error: Attempted to prefetch a URL that does not belong to this app ``` **What I expect to happen:** The error should not be thrown.

payload.description: Run a local version of the MongoDB Atlas "Data API".

commits.message: fix: enforce application/json mime type response

payload.description: Run a local version of the MongoDB Atlas "Data API".

issue.title: Some confusion getting started using for the first time
issue.body:
Hello,

My team is considering using the Data API and wanted to know if there was an option for local development and so I came across your project. Thank you for releasing it. 

I ran into some issues while trying it out:

The README made me think I had to use the `setup` function which didn't make sense to me, but I eventually got a query to work with curl after studying the source code. Would have been nice if the README showed an example using curl and then I think some of my confusion would have been minimized.

Had to look in the code to see the URLs should start with /action instead of the longer URLs in the examples in the Data API docs. I think this is OK because we can configure any base URL we want and just append /find, /insertOne, etc.

Did not know what to put in `dataSource` until I saw the code that said it was ignored.

Only POST requests seem to work but some of the examples in the official docs show GET requests. Also not a big deal but was getting not found errors until I realized this.

When my local MongoDB doesn't require a username or password, omitting those options doesn't work. Using a simple `--url` option without username and password in the URL works, though.

Sending `Accept: application/ejson` seems to return the same data as application/json. I don't know yet if we will want to use ejson but I'm guessing you don't in your projects since it's not implemented?

In the end, I got it working so it's very nice to have the option of using your tool. I know I could have submitted multiple issues but didn't want to spam you.

I have a question. Do you use this on projects for work and find it valuable? I think I'd be OK with just using Atlas but I like having options, too, and don't want to prevent anybody from developing offline if they want to.

Thanks again.

issue.title: Outstanding bugs in the MongoDB Data API
issue.body:
These are known issues with the MongoDB Atlas Data API, which are implemented in this version for accuracy.

I'll write them as checkboxes, and as the MongoDB dev team fixes them, I'll update this library.

- [x] The `/deleteOne` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`
- [x] The `/deleteMany` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`
- [x] The `/find` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`
- [x] The `/findOne` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`
- [x] The `/insertOne` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`
- [x] The `/insertMany` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`
- [x] The `/replaceOne` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`
- [x] The `/updateOne` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`
- [x] The `/updateMany` response returns `Content-Type` as `text/plain`

Other things possibly not bugs but will probably change later:

- [x] The `/insertMany` doesn't return the `insertedCount` on the response.
- [x] The `/updateMany` doesn't return the `updatedCount` on the response.

commits.message: docs: clarity on what went v1

comment.body: MongoDB Atlas Data API is out of beta, and these things are all finally resolved.

issue.title: MongoDB Data API is out of beta
issue.body:
Thanks to the note in #1 from @da7a90-backup I was informed that v1 is out.

With that, I'll update this library to v1 as well! 🎉

The breaking change is basically just on the init side, but also note that the Data API v1 has more consistent responses (when it returns JSON it always sets `Content-Type: application/json` instead of sometimes `text/plain`).

### Added
- Full test suite (it's the demo code) that actually connects to a MongoDB Data API
  instance to verify that all requests are being made correctly. (Note to my future
  self: this is using a free version, which will likely be automatically spun down
  due to inactivity. I will need to go spin it back up for tests to pass.)
### Changed
- BREAKING: Simplified the interface a bit, by requiring the fully qualified URL instead of region
  and/or app ID. Here are the [MongoDB URL docs](https://www.mongodb.com/docs/atlas/api/data-api-resources/#base-url).
- BREAKING: Renamed `cluster` to `dataSource` to match their parameter names better.
- Change the default-vs-overrides a bit: you don't *need* to specify the `dataSource`, `database`,
  or `collection` properties at initialization. If you do, you can still specify them at
  the request to override the defaults.

# Migration

Anywhere you are instantiating `mongodb`, you will need to...

Change `cluster` to `dataSource`:

```diff
const db = mongodb({
	apiKey,
	apiUrl,
-	cluster,
+	dataSource,
	database,
	collection,
})
```

If you are using `apiId` / `apiRegion` you will need to construct the URL yourself:

```diff
const db = mongodb({
	apiKey,
-	apiId,
-	apiRegion,
+	apiUrl: 'https://data.mongodb-api.com/app/YOUR_ID/endpoint/data/v1',
	dataSource,
	database,
	collection,
})
```

(Look at the [MongoDB Data API docs](https://www.mongodb.com/docs/atlas/api/data-api-resources/#base-url) for additional guidance on URLs.)

comment.body: Ugh yes, I see that now, thanks for the heads up 🤦‍♂️ I'll fix it early next week.

payload.description: Simple wrapper for the MongoDB Data API.

commits.message: feature: add ability to interpose right before request

issue.body: this got me scratching my head for a very long time until I tested using Postman and went through the wrapper code that I noticed the API endpoint is still in beta. changed it to v1 now it's working again.

comment.body:
@da7a90-backup I did some other misc. tasks while updating this, see #2 for details.

Thanks again!

issue.title: Sample for downloading an attachment?
issue.body:
I've been reading through the JMAP specs and the Fastmail docs, and I can't figure out how to use JMAP to fetch an individual attachment from an email.

* Is this even possible? I can use other methods to get the attachment bytes, but it has all the other metadata (mime-type, name, blob id, etc) so that it feels like it should be right there.
* If it's possible, can it be added to this repo as an example? (I could make a PR once I understand it.)
* If it's not possible, is there a related Fastmail API that I could use instead?

This is just so I can test Github site stuff.

pull_request.title: CLI designed and dependency licensing considerations
pull_request.body:
* The general structure of the code, as well as the command line options, have been finalized.
* The core code for the CLI portion has been added.
* The CLI code makes use of dependencies. Licenses for all dependencies that are used in the distributed, compiled code will be kept in a new `licensing` folder.
* All dependencies, whether for distributed or development, will be pinned to exact values for clearer licensing and security analysis.

issue.title: Add accessibility attributes
issue.body:
I've been reading through some ARIA docs and realized this component should probably just be a [`progress`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/progress) element, but if not it at least needs the [`role=progressbar`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/roles/progressbar_role) attribute.

In addition, I need to read through the docs, but there are some ARIA properties (labels, `valuenow`, etc) that should be set, and some guidance documented on the proper way to place this in a page for screen readers.

issue.title: Strange artifact in Psalms 34
issue.body: You can see it here https://github.com/TehShrike/world-english-bible/blob/master/json/psalms.json#L11060 Where in chapter 34, verse number 22 comes first. I'll see if I can dig into it this weekend.

issue.title: feature: add support for ejson
issue.body:
PR for #3.

co-body is the package koa-body uses to parse the request body, but koa-body will only do that when content-type is in a small, non-extensible list of types that does not include application/ejson.

A co-worker and I have already had one successful day using this fork without any issues so far.

comment.body: Okay yeah, that does look pretty great 👍 I'm pretty cramped for time this week, but I'll keep this tagged on my end and try to merge and release this week or weekend. Thanks!!!

issue.title: Support for application/ejson
issue.body:
I'm using application/ejson with the real data API to ensure my dates are stored as dates and not as strings.

I'm finally getting mongodb-local-data-api set up at work because the real data API is so slow to develop with. (I hope this is because I'm still using a free cluster for my proof of concept, and it will be faster once we start paying...)

When I send a request with application/ejson in the content-type header to mongodb-local-data-api, I get back a 400 and see messages like this logged to the console:

```
Attempting to connect to: undefined
Error handling request: Collection name must be a String
```

It looks to me like the koa-body middleware is not parsing the request body because application/ejson is not in its hard-coded list of acceptable types for JSON and there is no option to extend that. 😢 

I can change my content-type to application/json and it starts to work but the data I'm sending in EJSON format is not being saved correctly.

I'm using the EJSON object in the bson package to stringify and parse this format. I think mongodb-local-data-api could use the same package to do the opposite depending on the content-type and accept headers it receives.

I've never used Koa, but I think this wouldn't be too hard to add so can attempt to send a PR if you think is this is correct.

comment.body: (Also, yes, once you upgrade the DB out of the free/sandbox mode, it's *much* faster, at least in my experience.)

issue.title: Support for application/ejson
issue.body:
I'm using application/ejson with the real data API to ensure my dates are stored as dates and not as strings.

I'm finally getting mongodb-local-data-api set up at work because the real data API is so slow to develop with. (I hope this is because I'm still using a free cluster for my proof of concept, and it will be faster once we start paying...)

When I send a request with application/ejson in the content-type header to mongodb-local-data-api, I get back a 400 and see messages like this logged to the console:

```
Attempting to connect to: undefined
Error handling request: Collection name must be a String
```

It looks to me like the koa-body middleware is not parsing the request body because application/ejson is not in its hard-coded list of acceptable types for JSON and there is no option to extend that. 😢 

I can change my content-type to application/json and it starts to work but the data I'm sending in EJSON format is not being saved correctly.

I'm using the EJSON object in the bson package to stringify and parse this format. I think mongodb-local-data-api could use the same package to do the opposite depending on the content-type and accept headers it receives.

I've never used Koa, but I think this wouldn't be too hard to add so can attempt to send a PR if you think is this is correct.

comment.body:
Yeah, if you wanted to make a PR that would be great!

Supporting ejson is in my personal todo list, but very low priority for me since I don't use it.

If you make a PR, I will test it locally and then (probably) tidy it slightly before cutting a release, but I'll be sure to credit you. ❤️

issue.title: Footer bar in REPL throws console error on hover
issue.body: **What I did:** Open a REPL in Firefox `105.0.2 (64-bit)` on macOS `12.4`, then open the dev console, then hover my mouse over the footer promo. **What happened:** On (every? most? there's probably throttling going on) mouseover events, I get a thrown console error: ``` Error: Attempted to prefetch a URL that does not belong to this app ``` **What I expect to happen:** The error should not be thrown.

comment.body:
Actually, it looks like this is related to https://github.com/sveltejs/kit/issues/6463 which was addressed here https://github.com/sveltejs/kit/pull/6518 but the issue doesn't seem to be addressed entirely since I would expect this error to not be thrown (at most a `console.warning`).

From the [SvelteKit docs](https://kit.svelte.dev/docs/link-options#disabling-options) it looks like we could just add the `data-sveltekit-prefetch="off"` on some parent node, at least for now.

issue.title: Some confusion getting started using for the first time
issue.body:
Hello,

My team is considering using the Data API and wanted to know if there was an option for local development and so I came across your project. Thank you for releasing it. 

I ran into some issues while trying it out:

The README made me think I had to use the `setup` function which didn't make sense to me, but I eventually got a query to work with curl after studying the source code. Would have been nice if the README showed an example using curl and then I think some of my confusion would have been minimized.

Had to look in the code to see the URLs should start with /action instead of the longer URLs in the examples in the Data API docs. I think this is OK because we can configure any base URL we want and just append /find, /insertOne, etc.

Did not know what to put in `dataSource` until I saw the code that said it was ignored.

Only POST requests seem to work but some of the examples in the official docs show GET requests. Also not a big deal but was getting not found errors until I realized this.

When my local MongoDB doesn't require a username or password, omitting those options doesn't work. Using a simple `--url` option without username and password in the URL works, though.

Sending `Accept: application/ejson` seems to return the same data as application/json. I don't know yet if we will want to use ejson but I'm guessing you don't in your projects since it's not implemented?

In the end, I got it working so it's very nice to have the option of using your tool. I know I could have submitted multiple issues but didn't want to spam you.

I have a question. Do you use this on projects for work and find it valuable? I think I'd be OK with just using Atlas but I like having options, too, and don't want to prevent anybody from developing offline if they want to.

Thanks again.

- BREAKING: Renamed `cluster` to `dataSource` to match their parameter names better.
- Change the default-vs-overrides a bit: you don't *need* to specify the `dataSource`, `database`,
  or `collection` properties at initialization. If you do, you can still specify them at
  the request to override the defaults.

# Migration

Anywhere you are instantiating `mongodb`, you will need to...

Change `cluster` to `dataSource`:

```diff
const db = mongodb({
	apiKey,
	apiUrl,
-	cluster,
+	dataSource,
	database,
	collection,
})
```

If you are using `apiId` / `apiRegion` you will need to construct the URL yourself:

```diff
const db = mongodb({
	apiKey,
-	apiId,
-	apiRegion,
+	apiUrl: 'https://data.mongodb-api.com/app/YOUR_ID/endpoint/data/v1',
	dataSource,
	database,
	collection,
})
```

(Look at the [MongoDB Data API docs](https://www.mongodb.com/docs/atlas/api/data-api-resources/#base-url) for additional guidance on URLs.)

comment.body: Ugh yes, I see that now, thanks for the heads up 🤦‍♂️ I'll fix it early next week.

repo.name: mongodb
repo.description: Simple wrapper for the MongoDB Data API.

pull_request.title: MongoDB Data API is out of beta
pull_request.body:
Thanks to the note in #1 from @da7a90-backup I was informed that v1 is out.

With that, I'll update this library to v1 as well! 🎉

The breaking change is basically just on the init side, but also note that the Data API v1 has more consistent responses (when it returns JSON it always sets `Content-Type: application/json` instead of sometimes `text/plain`).

### Added
- Full test suite (it's the demo code) that actually connects to a MongoDB Data API
  instance to verify that all requests are being made correctly. (Note to my future
  self: this is using a free version, which will likely be automatically spun down
  due to inactivity. I will need to go spin it back up for tests to pass.)
### Changed
- BREAKING: Simplified the interface a bit, by requiring the fully qualified URL instead of region
  and/or app ID. Here are the [MongoDB URL docs](https://www.mongodb.com/docs/atlas/api/data-api-resources/#base-url).
- BREAKING: Renamed `cluster` to `dataSource` to match their parameter names better.
- Change the default-vs-overrides a bit: you don't *need* to specify the `dataSource`, `database`,
  or `collection` properties at initialization. If you do, you can still specify them at
  the request to override the defaults.

# Migration

Anywhere you are instantiating `mongodb`, you will need to...

Change `cluster` to `dataSource`:

```diff
const db = mongodb({
	apiKey,
	apiUrl,
-	cluster,
+	dataSource,
	database,
	collection,
})
```

If you are using `apiId` / `apiRegion` you will need to construct the URL yourself:

```diff
const db = mongodb({
	apiKey,
-	apiId,
-	apiRegion,
+	apiUrl: 'https://data.mongodb-api.com/app/YOUR_ID/endpoint/data/v1',
	dataSource,
	database,
	collection,
})
```

(Look at the [MongoDB Data API docs](https://www.mongodb.com/docs/atlas/api/data-api-resources/#base-url) for additional guidance on URLs.)

issue.title: Sample for downloading an attachment?
issue.body:
I've been reading through the JMAP specs and the Fastmail docs, and I can't figure out how to use JMAP to fetch an individual attachment from an email.

* Is this even possible? I can use other methods to get the attachment bytes, but it has all the other metadata (mime-type, name, blob id, etc) so that it feels like it should be right there.
* If it's possible, can it be added to this repo as an example? (I could make a PR once I understand it.)
* If it's not possible, is there a related Fastmail API that I could use instead?

pull_request.title: CLI designed and dependency licensing considerations
pull_request.body:
* The general structure of the code, as well as the command line options, have been finalized.
* The core code for the CLI portion has been added.
* The CLI code makes use of dependencies. Licenses for all dependencies that are used in the distributed, compiled code will be kept in a new `licensing` folder.
* All dependencies, whether for distributed or development, will be pinned to exact values for clearer licensing and security analysis.
